column3: It does make me wonder why the macro is in `strencodings.h`, which now needs to be included everywwhere. Maybe it would be better to move it to a separate header first.
It was moved from `src/util.h` to `src/utilstrencodings.h` (which was later moved to `src/util/strencodings.h`) back in 2014: ad49c256c33bfe4088fd3c7ecb7d28cb81a8fc70
There is a better way to do it in C++ actually, see https://github.com/kristapsk/resclib/blob/0df895a9f02d393791590aa79c0022476ac1721a/include/stdlib.h#L51.
Also, `_countof` is [supported by default in Microsoft C/C++ lib](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/c-runtime-library/reference/countof-macro?view=vs-2019).
C++17 has `std::size` for this. We could backport it, or just wait.

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

### Conflicts

* #16439 (cli/gui: support "@he
> C++17 has std::size for this. We could backport it, or just wait.\n\nLet's just wait IMO. There is no hurry in the world to do this. The current solution works perfectly for the meantime.

Thanks for all of your feedback. The initial idea of this PR was just to make use of a macro that is already there to increase readability of the code. The answers in the code suggested some more ideas, each of them valid -- to summarize:\n* moving the macro from `strencodings.h` to a more appropriate header (probably a new one)\n* changing from the C way of determining the size of an array to t
The idx isn't needed, so a C++11 range-based for loop would be better suited.\n\nSee conflicting pull #19528
